subsc: Central government administration,Other social services,Health,General education sector
sectr: Public Administration, Law, and Justice,Health and other social services,Education

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Uganda HIV/AIDS Control
            Project were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: 1) there is a need for a more
            focused multi-sectoral approach which prioritizes sectors
            with the largest potential impact on the epidemic such as
            health, education, transport, labor, gender and defense on
            the basis of their comparative advantages; 2) the risk of
            scaling up care and treatment agenda at the expense of
            prevention is real; 3) there is a need to put in place
            functional mechanisms for coordination, alignment and
            harmonization of the major funding streams for HIV/AIDS; and
            4) no corruption/governance issue was identified, and this
            can be attributed to the use of the independent Technical
            Resource Network, the project's emphasis on
            transparency and accountability of budget allocation and
            expenditures, clear eligibility criteria for implementers,
            the contracting of accounting firms to help the districts
            with financial management issues, and fiduciary capacity
            building for civil society organizations (CSOs).
